articles.headline: How Not to Overpay on Black Friday? Let the Web Be Your Guide
articles.snippet: Despite what the ads say, the overwhelming majority of deals on the day after Thanksgiving are duds.
articles.abstract: Despite what the ads say, the overwhelming majority of deals on the day after Thanksgiving are duds.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATTENTION holiday shoppers, here is your annual public service announcement: The overwhelming majority of Black Friday deals are duds.

articles.headline: Across China, Walmart Faces Labor Unrest as Authorities Stand Aside
articles.snippet: Workers are bypassing Communist Party unions and are appealing to nationalist ideals, though the government has long discouraged labor activism.
articles.abstract: Workers are bypassing Communist Party unions and are appealing to nationalist ideals, though the government has long discouraged labor activism.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — In a one-man war room in his apartment, a laid-off Walmart employee named Wang Shishu was tapping out a message on his phone to a group of workers and plotting his next move.

articles.headline: Senate Democrats’ Surprising Strategy: Trying to Align With Trump
articles.snippet: Democrats will try to find common cause with Donald J. Trump on infrastructure spending, child tax credits and dismantling trade agreements.
articles.abstract: Democrats will try to find common cause with Donald J. Trump on infrastructure spending, child tax credits and dismantling trade agreements.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Democrats, divided and struggling for a path from the electoral wilderness, are constructing an agenda to align with many proposals of President-elect Donald J. Trump that put him at odds with his own party.

articles.headline: Minneapolis Fed Chief Proposes Eliminating ‘Too Big to Fail’ Banks
articles.snippet: On the surface, Mr. Kashkari’s plan would seem to be a tough sell in the new Trump administration, requiring banks to boost their capital by carrying steep costs.
articles.abstract: On the surface, Mr. Kashkari’s plan would seem to be a tough sell in the new Trump administration, requiring banks to boost their capital by carrying steep costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street banks are still too big to fail, and the hundreds of thousands of pages of regulations created in the eight years since the crisis are not adequate protection against another financial shock, says Neel Kashkari of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Is Said to Settle Bribery Case Over Hiring in China
articles.snippet: Federal authorities are expected to announce a roughly $264 million settlement with the bank over charges that it hired children of Chinese leaders in exchange for deals.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities are expected to announce a roughly $264 million settlement with the bank over charges that it hired children of Chinese leaders in exchange for deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than three years of digging into JPMorgan Chase’s hiring practices in China, federal authorities have determined that the bank hired the children of Chinese leaders as part of a quid pro quo to win business in the booming nation, clearing the way for a costly punishment.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Specter of Race Shadows Jeff Sessions, Potential Trump Nominee for Cabinet
articles.snippet: Accusations of racial comments doomed the 1986 court nomination of Mr. Sessions, an Alabama senator under consideration for attorney general or defense secretary.
articles.abstract: Accusations of racial comments doomed the 1986 court nomination of Mr. Sessions, an Alabama senator under consideration for attorney general or defense secretary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 1981, a Justice Department prosecutor from Washington stopped by to see Jeff Sessions, the United States attorney in Mobile, Ala., at the time. The prosecutor, J. Gerald Hebert, said he had heard a shocking story: A federal judge had called a prominent white lawyer “a disgrace to his race” for representing black clients.

articles.headline: A Mother Tried to Escape Gangs. Bullets Found Her Daughter.
articles.snippet: At 15, Veronica Lopez knew death. Ultimately it caught up with her on a Chicago roadway.
articles.abstract: At 15, Veronica Lopez knew death. Ultimately it caught up with her on a Chicago roadway.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — At Veronica Lopez’s Sweet 16 party, children played among the headstones. Aunts, uncles and cousins sat on lawn chairs and striped blankets on the grass. A few feet away from Veronica’s grave, her four older sisters pressed candles into a red velvet cake and carefully lit them.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Catrin Einhorn

articles.headline: Yellen: Too Soon to Predict Economic Effects of Election
articles.snippet: In her first public comments since the election, the central bank chief also signaled that the Fed remained likely to raise interest rates next month.
articles.abstract: In her first public comments since the election, the central bank chief also signaled that the Fed remained likely to raise interest rates next month.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said Thursday it was too soon to predict the economic impact of Donald J. Trump’s election as the next president of the United States.

articles.headline: Intensified by Climate Change, ‘King Tides’ Change Ways of Life in Florida
articles.snippet: King tides, which frequently flood South Florida even when the sun shines, are the most blatant example of the interplay between rising seas and the alignment of the moon, sun and Earth.
articles.abstract: King tides, which frequently flood South Florida even when the sun shines, are the most blatant example of the interplay between rising seas and the alignment of the moon, sun and Earth.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — In an enclave of a city known as the Venice of America, where dream-big houses look out over a maze of picturesque canals, the comparison to the Venice of Italy no longer seems so appealing.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Son-in-Law, Jared Kushner, Tests Legal Path to White House Job
articles.snippet: Such a move could violate federal anti-nepotism law and risk legal challenges and political backlash.
articles.abstract: Such a move could violate federal anti-nepotism law and risk legal challenges and political backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jared Kushner, the son-in-law of President-elect Donald J. Trump, has spoken to a lawyer about the possibility of joining the new administration, a move that could violate federal anti-nepotism law and risk legal challenges and political backlash.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Trump-Size Idea for a New President: Build Something Inspiring
articles.snippet: The right public works projects can send a message of inclusion and pride. If Donald Trump is ready to take a cue from F.D.R., here are some places to start.
articles.abstract: The right public works projects can send a message of inclusion and pride. If Donald Trump is ready to take a cue from F.D.R., here are some places to start.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s how President-elect Trump could unify a bitterly divided America, provide well-paying jobs to many of the millions of disaffected workers who voted for him, and lift the economy, stock market and tax rolls.

articles.headline: Former Drug Industry Executives Charged in Kickback Scheme
articles.snippet: Gary Tanner, the former Valeant executive, entered into a secret relationship with Philidor’s chief executive, Andrew Davenport, federal authorities said.
articles.abstract: Gary Tanner, the former Valeant executive, entered into a secret relationship with Philidor’s chief executive, Andrew Davenport, federal authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: A secret relationship had made the two men rich: one, the head of a mail-order pharmacy, the other, an executive at a major pharmaceutical company who had promised to funnel millions of dollars to his partner in exchange for receiving millions of his own.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: JPMorgan Chase to Pay $264 Million to Settle Foreign Bribery Case
articles.snippet: The case centers on JPMorgan’s hiring practices in China, where it is accused of hiring the children of Chinese leaders to win business there.
articles.abstract: The case centers on JPMorgan’s hiring practices in China, where it is accused of hiring the children of Chinese leaders to win business there.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vying for lucrative deals in China, JPMorgan Chase deployed all the usual wining-and-dining tactics that big banks use to woo clients. JPMorgan, federal authorities now say, also had ways of sweetening the deal that crossed a legal line.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson
